Supported mesoporous Pt catalysts with excellent performance for toluene hydrogenation under low reaction pressure Yang Yang a b Xinzhang Lin a Jie Tang a b Jubo Zhang a Chao Liu a ⁎ Jiahui Huang a ⁎ a Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, PR China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian 116023 PR China aDalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, PR China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 PR China bUniversity of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Aromatic hydrogenation is a matter of great importance because of its multiple applications and meaningfulness in environmental protection. However, lowering the reaction pressure for toluene hydrogenation with suitable catalyst is a primary challenge. Hence, in this work, we report good catalytic performance of toluene hydrogenation using supported mesoporous Pt (MP) under low reaction pressure. The MP has porous morphology and particle diameter is around 50 nm. The whole structure is constituted by mutual-connected Pt nanoparticles with size of 3-5 nm. Owing to the abundant highly exposed Pt atoms of MP and electron transfer between MP and support, MP catalyst shows a superior catalytic performance than traditional Pt nanoparticle catalysts under lower reaction pressure. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords mesoporous Pt nanoparticle toluene hydrogenation reaction pressure 1 Introduction Aromatic hydrogenation has attracted extensive attention due to its environmental potential and wide range of application. Hydrogenated product of benzene, cyclohexane, is an indispensable intermediate for producing Nylon-6 and Nylon-66 [1]. In addition, this process is also effective for eliminating superfluous aromatic compounds in fuels [2], as a result, plays an important role in fuel refinery [3]. Besides, methylcyclohexane, as hydrogenation product of toluene, is also commonly used in rubber, coating, grease, and organic synthesis [4,5]. In comparison with benzene, toluene is a more suitable option due to the similar chemical property and much lower toxicity [6–8]. Zhu et al. [9] achieved an optimal toluene conversion by adjusting the size and morphology of Ni nanoflower. Suppino et al. [10] deposited Fe, Ni and Co nanoparticles on Al2O3 by wet impregnation method and explored toluene conversion by changing the activation methods. Cobo et al. [11] selected di-metal catalyst, PtRu/Al2O3 and PdRu/Al2O3 in order to enhance toluene conversion. Loiha et al. [12] developed a bimetallic PtPd catalyst for toluene hydrogenation, a full conversion of toluene and 100% selectivity of methylcyclohexane was achieved under a mild reaction condition. Pt based catalysts are widely used in toluene hydrogenation [1,3,8,11,13,14]. Nevertheless, the requirement of high reaction pressure [10,11,13,15,16] should be addressed in this catalytic reaction. Recently, porous noble metal has been investigated widely due to its high surface area and low transfer barricade for reactants and products [17–19]. The synthesis of porous noble metal mainly contains three methods. (1) de-alloying method. Asao et al. [20] selectively leached silver from Au30Ag70 alloy to obtain porous gold leaf and applied it to catalyze oxidation of organosilanes with H2O as oxidant. Subsequently, Yamamoto et al. [21] applied similar method to obtain nano porous gold catalyst and used it in [4+2] benzannulation between ortho-alkynylbenzaldehydes and alkynes. Kaneko et al. [22] utilized de-alloying method to synthesize a porous Pd catalyst which exhibited an excellent catalytic performance for Heck reaction of various aryl iodides and aryl bromides. (2) Hard templating. This is another method to prepare porous noble metal. Shin et al. [23] chose MCM-48 as the hard template to synthesize porous Pt nanoparticles (NPs). The TEM images of porous Pt NPs strongly suggested that the nanostructure of MCM-48 was successfully replicated. Wang et al. [24] used KIT-6 and SBA-15 as hard templates to synthesize Pt NPs with ordered porous structure and uniform size distribution. For hard templating method, migration of metal precursor during reduction causes the whole process uncontrollable. Fang et al. [25] proposed soft-enveloping strategy to solve this problem. (3) Soft templating. This method is also widely employed in preparation of porous noble metal. Eid et al. [26] applied PVP and L-ascorbic acid as soft template and reducing agent, respectively, to prepare porous Pt-based NPs. A serial of bimetallic porous nanoparticles including PtPd, AuPt, PtCu and PtNi were synthesized. These nanomaterials could efficiently catalyze glucose oxidation over a wide pH range. In Recent, porous NPs which contains three metal components, Pt, Pd, and Ru was prepared by the similar method [27]. The PtPdRu porous NPs exhibited an outstanding capability of tolerating CO-poisoning during ethanol oxidation reaction. Although the porous noble metal has been synthesized by various methods and applied in different fields, there is no report about utilizing this excellent material in toluene hydrogenation. Hence, in this work, supported mesoporous Pt (MP) was synthesized by soft templating method and applied in toluene hydrogenation for the purpose of improving catalytic performance and reducing reaction pressure. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation MP was synthesized by the reported method [26] with minor modifications. Briefly, 160 mg K2PtCl4 was dissolved in 40 mL deionized water, followed by adding 0.96 g PVP with a molecular weight of 24000. Afterwards, 4 ml L-ascorbic acid (0.4 mol/L) was added under sonication and kept for 150 min. Subsequently, the mixture which changed into black was put in a water bath at 45 °C for 21 h. Then, the powder was obtained by centrifugation and washed with 45 °C water. Finally, MP was dried in vacuum oven under room temperature. As-prepared MP was loaded on various supports including active carbon (AC), Al2O3, NiO, and CeO2. As a typical example, 10 mg MP was dispersed in 25 mL deionized water under magnetic stirring and kept stirring for another 10 min. Then, 0.5 g support was added into the above solution and kept stirring for 4 h. Afterwards, the powder was acquired by centrifugation and dried in vacuum oven under room temperature. Finally, the catalyst was calcined under air or N2 atmosphere at different temperature (100 - 500 °C) with a ramping rate of 2 °C/min for 2 h. The obtained catalysts were denoted as MP/support-A (or N)-X, where support is AC, CeO2, Al2O3 and NiO, X means the calcination temperature, A and N represent calcination atmosphere is air and nitrogen, respectively. After deciding the most optimal support, calcination atmosphere, and calcination temperature, additional reduction under H2 flow (maintaining temperature of 200 °C for 2 h, 2 °C/min of ramping rate) was conducted. In order to completely illustrate the advantage of MP catalyst, traditional Pt NPs catalysts were also prepared by the wet impregnation method [28] and colloid method [29]. For the wet impregnation method, 352 mg K2PtCl4 and 1 g CeO2 were added into 50 mL deionized water under stirring. After stirring for 6 h, the powder was centrifuged and dried in vacuum oven at room temperature. Finally, the powder was reduced under H2 flow at 200 °C for 2 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C/min. This catalyst was denoted as Pt/CeO2-1. In terms of colloid method, 570 mg PVP (MW=8000), 310 mg H2PtCl6• 6H2O were dissolved in 100 mL deionized water. Then, 10 mL ice aqueous solution containing 100 mg NaBH4 was added. Subsequently, 2 g CeO2 was added into above mixture. Finally, the post treatment for this catalyst follows the most optimal pattern which was determined by MP catalyst serials. It was denoted as Pt/CeO2-2. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of as-synthesized MP was analyzed by PANalytical Empyrean-100 with a Cu Kα X-ray source operated at 40 kV and 30 mA, scanning speed was 5 o/min. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) were practiced by using JEOL JEM-2100 electron microscope with a transmission voltage of 200 KV. The sample was ultrasonic dispersed in alcohol and supported on carbon film or copper mesh. Thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) was practiced by METTLER TOLEDO TGA2. Ramping rate was set as 2 °C/min, and atmosphere was air with a flow rate of 100 mL/min. BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore size were determined by Micromeritics ASAP 2020 HD88. The sample was degassed under 150 °C for 10 h. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analysis was conducted on SHIMADZU ICPS-8100. Sample was dissolved in aqua regia under sonication, and then the solution was centrifugated and diluted to certain concentration. CO-FTIR spectrum of catalysts was obtained by utilizing BRUKER VERTEX 70. The sample was firstly purged by N2 flow (30 mL/min) for 30 min to get a stable baseline. Afterwards, the atmosphere was changed to 10% CO/N2 (30 ml/min) and maintained under this atmosphere until the height of CO adsorption peak was constant. Then, the atmosphere was changed back to N2 (30 mL/min) to remove physical adsorbed CO. NH3-TPD was practiced on Micromeritics AutoChem II. The sample was firstly pretreated by He at 150 °C for 1 h. Then, it was cooled to 100 °C and 10% NH3/He was introduced to sample tube. After adsorbing NH3 for 0.5 h, the sample was purged by He for 0.5 h to remove physical adsorbed NH3. CO2-TPD was conducted on Micromeritics AutoChem II. The sample was firstly pretreated by He at 150 °C for 1 h. Then, it was cooled to 50 °C to adsorb CO2 (15% CO2/He) for 0.5 h. The physical adsorbed CO2 was removed by He flow at the same temperature for 0.5 h. H2-TPD was investigated on Micromeritics AutoChem II. The sample was treated by He at 150 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 30 °C to adsorb H2 for 0.5 h. After the sample was purged by He at 30 °C for 0.5 h, the temperature program was initiated. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted on Thermofisher Excalab X+ using a standard Al Kα mono-chromated flood source (150 W, pass energy = 200 eV, spot size = 500 μm). All binding energies were referenced to C 1s peak at 284.8 eV of the surface adventitious carbon to correct the shift caused by charge effect. CO-pulse experiment was practiced for acquiring the Pt dispersion of MP/CeO2-A-400. Before pulse experiment, MP/CeO2 was calcined under air flow (30 mL/min) with ramping rate of 2 °C/min and maintained at 400 °C for 2 h in sample tube. Then, the prepared MP/CeO2-A-400 was cooled to 30 °C and CO-pulse was initiated. 2.3 Catalytic performance test Toluene hydrogenation in liquid phase was conducted in a 25 mL stainless steel autoclave. 20 mg catalyst, 100 μL toluene and 13.5 mL isopropanol were added into autoclave. The amount of catalyst was adjusted according to the result of ICP analysis to maintain the molar ratio of Pt to toluene at 1/1000 (the loading of Pt is seen in Table S1). After adding reaction mixture, reactor was sealed and then pressurized/depressurized under H2 flow for 5 cycles. Subsequently, the reaction temperature and pressure were set. The reaction time and stirring speed were 3 h and 1200 rpm, respectively. Organic sample was collected after finishing reaction and analyzed on Agilent 7890B GC/5977A MSD. Methylcyclohexane is the only product for all catalysts. Since all the catalysts have the same selectivity of 100% to methylcyclohexane, conversion of toluene is adapted as the criterion to assess the catalytic performance. For the recycling experiment, the used catalyst was washed by 30 mL isopropanol for five times and dried under vacuum at room temperature. The volume of toluene for recycling reaction was adjusted according to the weight loss of catalyst during the washing process. 3 Results and discussion Morphology of as-prepared MP was examined with TEM, which is shown in Fig. 1 a, b. It is found that as-prepared MP has a porous morphology with particle diameter of around 50 nm. This morphology was further investigated by HRTEM analysis. The part indicated by red square box in Fig. 1b is enlarged in Fig. 1c, which shows that the porous structure is formed by mutual-connected Pt NPs with an average size of 3.6 nm (Fig. 1d). The lattice of Pt NPs can be clearly observed (Fig. 1c). XRD pattern of MP reveals the particles have high crystallinity (Fig. 2 ), peak positions and FWHM are summarized in Table S2. Diffraction peaks at about 39°, 47°, 67°, 82°, and 86° are attributed to the (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) facets of the Pt face-centred cubic (fcc) structure, respectively. According to the peak width at half-height of 5 reflections and Scherrer formula, the calculated average size of Pt particle is 3.3 nm (Table S2). This further proves that porous structure of as-synthesized MP is formed by mutual-linked Pt NPs, which is in accordance with the result of HRTEM analysis. These characterizations indicate the formation process of our MP follows the mechanism proposed by Allam [26]. Unsupported MP may encounter some problems in catalysis. It is difficult to remove PVP that envelops active sites of MP (Fig. S1) without causing MP aggregation. Besides, separating MP from reaction mixture is tough due to its nanoscale size. Loading MP on support can solve these problems. AC, CeO2, Al2O3, and NiO were selected as support. Considering the residual PVP in MP, calcination in air or N2 for MP/AC was conducted for determining the most optimal calcination atmosphere, results are summarized in Fig. 3 a. Because of the low toluene conversion achieved by MP/AC-N-400, we did not calcinate the catalyst with higher calcination temperature in N2 atmosphere. The highest calcination temperature under air atmosphere is 300 °C, which is based on the burning point of AC. It is found that the best catalytic performance of MP/AC is achieved by air calcination at 200 °C (Conv. 14.6%), which is much higher than those of N2 calcination at different temperature (highest Conv. only 2.2%) and uncalcined one (Conv. 3.2%). Therefore, air calcination is selected as the optimal calcination atmosphere for other supported MP catalysts. The catalytic performance of supported catalysts with different supports (NiO, CeO2 and Al2O3) was investigated (Fig. 3b). For these MP catalysts, calcination under air atmosphere is also indispensable for improving the catalytic performance. Catalytic performance of MP/NiO increases after calcination, 2.8% for before calcination versus 16.0% for after calcination. This trend is noticed on other supported MP catalysts as well. Toluene conversion for uncalcined and calcined MP/Al2O3 catalyst are 6.4% and 18.8%, respectively. MP/CeO2 also experiences distinct improvement on catalytic performance after calcination. Calcined MP/CeO2 shows a much superior performance of 25.1% than uncalcined one of 7.7%. Among these catalysts, CeO2 supported MP exhibits the best catalytic performance. Hence, different calcination temperature was adapted for this catalyst (Fig. 4 ). Compared with uncalcined one, MP/CeO2-A-100 displays lower toluene conversion of 2.2%. Catalytic performance is remarkably improved when calcination temperature is 200 °C and the toluene conversion reaches 25.1%. Notably, the activity of MP/CeO2 catalyst increases with the increase of calcination temperature. MP/CeO2-A-400 shows the best catalytic performance (Fig. 4). Carbon balance is 100.66%, which is calculated by using n-heptane as the internal standard. However, the toluene conversion of the catalyst reduces when the calcination temperature is increased to 500 °C. To investigate the effect of reduction atmosphere on catalytic activity, H2 reduction was conducted for MP/CeO2-A-400. However, toluene conversion decays to 14.0% (Fig. 4), indicating that additional H2 reduction process is useless and counterproductive. We applied TEM and EDX analysis to investigate the reason of much lower toluene conversion of MP/CeO2-A-400-H (denoted as 400-H in Fig. 4), and the results are summarized in Fig. S5. After being treated by H2, MP suffers serious aggregation, which should be responsible for the deterioration in catalytic performance. Meanwhile, the unsupported MP (the uncalcined and calcined at different temperature in air) was conducted to catalyze toluene hydrogenation, and the results are summarized in Fig. S2. Calcination can improve the catalytic performance of unsupported MP as well, the highest toluene conversion of 35.5% is achieved over calcined MP at 300 °C. Compared with the catalytic performance of MP/CeO2-A-400 (toluene conversion of 58.6%), this of unsupported MP is much lower, which reveals the necessity of loading MP on CeO2. To understand the influence of air calcination on the catalytic performance, TGA and TEM were applied to characterize CeO2 supported MP catalysts. TGA spectra (Fig. S3) indicate that part of PVP which covers active sites of MP can be removed via 400 °C calcination. All the PVP can be completely removed at calcination temperature of 500 °C. TEM images of MP/CeO2, MP/CeO2-A-400, and MP/CeO2-A-500 are shown in Fig. 5 and Fig. S4. Compared with MP/CeO2, the porous structure of MP/CeO2-A-400 partially maintains (Fig. 5), while serious agglomeration is observed on MP/CeO2-A-500 (Fig. S4). Hence, for MP/CeO2, calcination at 400 °C under air atmosphere can effectively remove the PVP to expose active sites without obviously destroying its porous morphology. It is worth mentioning that the optimal calcination temperatures for catalysts with different supports are different. The optimal calcination temperature for MP/NiO, MP/AC, MP/Al2O3, and MP/CeO2 is 200 °C, 200 °C, 300 °C, and 400 °C, respectively (Fig. 3a & Fig. 4& Fig. S6). In order to understand this phenomenon, CO-FTIR and XPS analysis were carried out. The CO absorption peak positions of MP/NiO-A-200, MP/Al2O3-A-300, and MP/CeO2-A-400 are 2098 cm−1, 2094 cm−1, and 2092 cm−1, which should be assigned to CO linear absorption on Pt surface [30–32] (Fig. 6 a). These results show that the supported MP of three catalysts are metallic state, according to previous report [33]. Of note, a red-shift of CO adsorption peak is observed on MP/CeO2-A-400, which illustrates the strongest electron transfer from CeO2 to MP [30,33,34]. This explains why MP/CeO2-A-400 exhibits the highest toluene conversion, since higher electron density can strengthen the hydrogen dissociation ability of Pt [35–37]. The XPS results of the Pt 4f core level spectra for MP/CeO2-A-400 and MP/AC-A-200 is shown in Fig. 6b. Details of peaks are summarized in Table S3. The Pt 4f7/2 peak at 71.00 eV for MP/CeO2-A-400 and 71.33 eV for MP/AC-A-200 should be assigned to Pt0 [38,39]. The lower binding energy of Pt 4f7/2 of MP/CeO2-A-400 than those of MP/AC-A-200 demonstrates that MP in MP/CeO2-A-400 has a higher electron density [40,41], which suggests stronger electron transform from CeO2 to MP. This is in consistent with the CO-FTIR analysis. BET surface area and porous structure of supports and supported MP catalysts are compared in Table S4. CeO2 and NiO have very small surface area, lower than 1 m2/g. The pore volume of these two supports is also quite small. Al2O3 and AC have much higher BET surface area and pore volume. The low pore properties of CeO2 and the highest toluene conversion of MP/CeO2-A-400 implies that the porous structure of supports have hardly influence in the catalytic performance in our case. Notably, the loading of MP has no effect on the BET surface area, pore volume, and pore size of support (similar pore properties of AC and MP/AC-A-200, Al2O3 and MP/Al2O3-A-300). The diameter of MP (∼50 nm) is much bigger than the pore sizes of four supports (from 3.76-22.07 nm), which indicates the fact that MP is loaded on the external surface instead of internal channels of supports. The information above suggests that the influence of BET surface area and porous structure of supports is negligible to the catalytic performance of supported MP catalysts. CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD were carried out to investigate the influence of acidity and basicity of different supports (Fig. 7 ). Large amount of both acidic sites and basic sites are presented on MP/AC-A-200 and MP/Al2O3-A-300. Only small quantity of basic sites is observed on MP/NiO-A-200 with the CO2 desorption temperature of about 181 °C and 602 °C. As for MP/CeO2-A-400, small number of acidic sites are found with the NH3 desorption temperature of about 368 °C. This unique acidic site of CeO2 may enhance the performance of MP/CeO2-A-400. Catalytic performance of MP/CeO2-A-400 under lower pressure was evaluated, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . A very interesting trend is found that toluene conversion significantly increases with the decrease of hydrogen pressure. Toluene conversion increases from initial 53.7% at 4.0 MPa to 75.5% at 3.0 MPa. When hydrogen pressure is further reduced to 1.0 MPa, a higher toluene conversion of 84.5% is acquired. The toluene conversion is 90.8% at the hydrogenation pressure as low as 0.5 MPa. However, the conversion drastically decreases at much lower pressure (0.2 MPa). According to the previously reported mechanism of toluene hydrogenation [42,43], there is a competitive adsorption between toluene and H2. When H2 pressure is excessively high (1.0 MPa∼4.0 MPa), superfluous hydrogen occupies active sites of MP since Pt is an excellent catalyst for hydrogen dissociation [44–46]. Under this circumstance, it is difficult for toluene to be adsorbed on active sites and hydrogenated subsequently. In terms of low toluene conversion at 0.2 MPa, this could be explained by the inadequate hydrogen concentration in liquid phase. Influence of reaction temperature was investigated under a hydrogen pressure of 0.5 MPa, results are summarized in Fig. 9. Among five reaction temperatures, 100 °C is the most optimal, toluene conversion is 90.8%. For two lower temperatures, catalytic performance decreases distinctly. Toluene conversion is 57.4% at 80 °C and 37.7% at 50 °C. Slower hydrogen dissociation rate under lower temperature is responsible for this inferior catalytic performance. When temperature is higher than 100 °C, catalytic performance is also worse than that of 100 °C, toluene conversion is 45.6% and 35.8% for 120 °C and 150 °C, respectively. Higher temperature boosts hydrogen dissociation, as mentioned before, and the formed excessive hydrogen atoms can occupy active sites and hinder toluene hydrogenation. To illustrate the superior catalytic performance of MP/CeO2-A-400 in toluene hydrogenation, two conventional Pt/CeO2 catalysts were prepared by impregnation (Pt/CeO2-1) and colloidal method (Pt/CeO2-2) for comparison (Table S5 & Fig. S7). When reaction condition was set as reaction temperature of 100 °C, reaction pressure of 4 MPa, and reaction time of 3 h, the toluene conversion achieved by MP/CeO2-A-400 is 58.6%, much higher than that of Pt/CeO2-1 and Pt/CeO2-2 (0.7% and 22.4%). Similar phenomenon was also observed when the reaction pressure was reduced to 0.5 MPa (Table S5). In order to explain the superior catalytic performance of MP/CeO2-A-400 than conventional Pt/CeO2 catalysts, H2-TPD characterization and kinetic experiment were carried out (Fig. S8). MP/CeO2-A-400 shows an obvious and broad H2 desorption peak at above 300 °C, which should be assigned to strong adsorption of hydrogen on MP/CeO2-A-400. In contrast, Pt/CeO2-2 only exhibits a weak peak at lower than 100 °C, and no noticeable peak can be found for Pt/CeO2-1. This big difference indicates that MP/CeO2-A-400 has a much stronger hydrogen adsorption ability than conventional Pt catalysts [47], which is beneficial for hydrogen activation and then toluene hydrogenation. Kinetic experiment was further carried out to understand the superiority of MP/CeO2-A-400. Since the catalytic performance of Pt/CeO2-1 is much inferior than Pt/CeO2-2, we compared apparent activation energy of MP/CeO2-A-400 and Pt/CeO2-2. The results show that the activation energy of MP/CeO2-A-400 is much lower than that of Pt/CeO2-2, which may explain the significant difference of catalytic performance of MP/CeO2-A-400 and conventional Pt catalysts. Since MP/CeO2-A-400 shows the most optimal catalytic performance among the investigated catalysts, it is selected to compare with other reported catalysts (Table 1 ). The TOF of MP/CeO2-A-400 (Pt dispersion of 14% obtained by CO-pulse experiment) is much higher than reported Pt, Ni, Pd, Fe, Co, Ir, Rh, Ru and PtRu catalyst [8–11,48–50]. The superior activity of MP/CeO2-A-400 should be attributed to abundant highly exposed Pt atoms, which are brought by the special morphology of MP [18,51-55]. Recycling experiment was carried out and result is shown in Fig. S9. Toluene conversion descends after recycling for once, which indicates the comparatively low reaction stability of MP. This could be owed to the collapse of porous structure of MP (Fig. S10) and the formation of carbonaceous residue [56,57]. Besides, after recycling, Pt leaching of MP/CeO2-A-400 is observed (Table S6) and the mean diameter of MP also increases to some extent (Fig. S11). The improvement for the stability of CeO2 supported MP catalysts will be conducted in the future work. 4 Conclusions In summary, various supported mesoporous Pt catalysts are synthesized and applied in toluene hydrogenation. Among these catalysts, CeO2 loaded mesoporous Pt catalyst exhibits the best catalytic performance. The highest toluene conversion of 90.8% is achieved when reaction temperature and pressure is 100 °C and 0.5 MPa, respectively. Comparing with traditional Pt nanoparticle catalysts, mesoporous Pt catalyst shows a superior catalytic performance under lower reaction pressure. Further optimization and application of this outstanding catalyst in other valuable hydrogen reactions is being explored. coredata.dc:description: Aromatic hydrogenation is a matter of great importance because of its multiple applications and meaningfulness in environmental protection. However, lowering the reaction pressure for toluene hydrogenation with suitable catalyst is a primary challenge. Hence, in this work, we report good catalytic performance of toluene hydrogenation using supported mesoporous Pt (MP) under low reaction pressure. The MP has porous morphology and particle diameter is around 50 nm. The whole structure is constituted by mutual-connected Pt nanoparticles with size of 3-5 nm. Owing to the abundant highly exposed Pt atoms of MP and electron transfer between MP and support, MP catalyst shows a superior catalytic performance than traditional Pt nanoparticle catalysts under lower reaction pressure.
coredata.dc:title: Supported mesoporous Pt catalysts with excellent performance for toluene hydrogenation under low reaction pressure
